SENT.plain: Inflammatory reactions occurring in the brain after ischemia may contribute to secondary damage
In the present study effects of minocycline, an anti-inflammatory agent, alone or in combination with mild hypothermia, on focal embolic brain ischemia have been examined
Focal ischemic injury was induced by embolizing a preformed clot into the middle cerebral artery (MCA)
Infarct volume was measured at 48 h after the injury
Administration of minocycline alone or minocycline plus mild hypothermia reduced infarct volume significantly
However, mild hypothermia in combination with minocycline did not show any additive effect
These results suggest that minocycline is beneficial in focal ischemic brain injury, and the lack of the enhanced neuroprotection may be due to the brief exposure to hypothermia
